folder: Columbus Circle & Broadway & 59th Street (West)., Manhattan, NY
text:
Columbus Circle, the intersecting hub point of Broadway, 59th Street, Central Park West and 8th Avenue-and an avenue leading on the east side through the park. The monument to Columbus, will be noted in the center of the circle.

No Record of Photography

c. 1900
title: Manhattan: Columbus Circle - Broadway - 59th Street (West).

folder: Columbus Circle & [59th Street & Broadway.], Manhattan, NY
text:
Columbus Circle, west side from and including 59th Street, to Broadway. Also shown is 59th Street, at and adjoining the N.W. corner of Columbus Circle.

About 1920.

I. Langran.
Gift of E. M. Jenks.
title: Manhattan: Columbus Circle - [59th Street - Broadway.]

text:
427-401 West 59th Street, at and adjoining the N.W. corner of Ninth Avenue, showing the 59th Street side of the Church of St. Paul the Apostle (Roman Catholic).

May 20, 1927.

P. L. Sperr.

folder: Columbus Circle and 59th Street, Manhattan, N.Y.
text:
Celebrations Parades Municipal Events:

(1)
Macy's Thanksgiving Parade, 1932, No.7, at Columbus Circle, looking north. A dachshund balloon being drawn past the Columbus Monument.
November 24, 1932
P.L.Sperr

(2)
No.8. Another view of the dachshund.
November 24, 1932
P.L.Sperr

(3)
No.9. Felix the Cat, proceeding east on 59th Street at Columbus Circle.
November 24, 1932
P.L.Sperr

folder: 59th Street (West) and Columbus Circle  , Manhattan, N.Y.
text:
(1)
Thanksgiving Ragamuffins, 1933, No. 64: 59th Street at Columbus Circle. These ragamuffins really are colored. This block, from Columbus Circle to Ninth Avenue, is part of the "San Juan Hill" negro colony, in the west 60's around Amsterdam Avenue and west to the river.
November 30, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
No. 65. Staten Island, on the grounds of the U. S. Government Quarantine Station near Fort Wadsworth, on the east side of the Island. The church steeple is that of St. John's Protestant Episcopal Church, on Bay Street.
November 30, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

(3)
No. 66. The same trio, seated.
November 30, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Thanksgiving ragamuffins, No.64-66.

Pawn Shop, 9 Columbus Avenue, east side, between 59th and 60th Streets.

April 30, 1934.

P. L. Sperr.

8 Columbus Circle, adjoining the S.W. corner of West 59th Street. View shows building wall being prepared for a bill board space at $ 50.000 rental per annum.

About 1934.

Ewing Galloway.
title: Manhattan: Columbus Circle - [59th Street (West).]

text:
320-326 West 59th Street, south side, between Columbus Circle and Ninth Ave. Nos. 320-324 are 3-story frame houses.

March 30, 1936.

P. L. Sperr.

Columbus Ave., east side, north from a point slightly north of West 59th Street. This thoroughfare after crossing this point loses its former identity as Ninth Ave. On the right is Kaskel's Pawn Shop (No. 9 Columbus Ave.) a well known feature of this area.

November 25, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.

W. 59th Street, north side, from Columbus Circle (right of No. 3) to Columbus Avenue (left of No. 1) as viewed from a clearance on the south side, showing a panoramic set of 3 views. No. 1 shows a row of tenements (No's 333 to 349) and a glimpse of the Roman Catholic Church of St. Paul the Apostle; the latter being at the S.W. corner of Columbus Avenue and W. 60th Street and is an outstanding feature of New York containing numerous works of art. No. 2 shows buildings near the Circle. These bear No's. 311 and 313-315. They are repeated in No. 3, being at the foot of the 23 story Gotham National Bank Building (No. 307). Note that the latter is not on the Circle as a thin veneer of structures line same.

September 4, 1938.
Views 1, 2 and 3.

P.L. Sperr

W. 59th Street, north side, from Columbus Circle (right of No. 3) to Columbus Avenue (left of No. 1) as viewed from a clearance on the south side, showing a panoramic set of 3 views. No. 1 shows a row of tenements (No's 333 to 349) and a glimpse of the Roman Catholic Church of St. Paul the Apostle; the latter being at the S.W. corner of Columbus Avenue and W. 60th Street and is an outstanding feature of New York containing numerous works of art. No. 2 shows buildings near the Circle. These bear No's. 311 and 313-315. They are repeated in No. 3, being at the foot of the 23 story Gotham National Bank Building (No. 307). Note that the latter is not on the Circle as a thin veneer of structures line same.

September 4, 1938.
Views 1, 2 and 3.

P.L. Sperr

W. 59th Street, north side, from Columbus Circle (right of No. 3) to Columbus Avenue (left of No. 1) as viewed from a clearance on the south side, showing a panoramic set of 3 views. No. 1 shows a row of tenements (No's 333 to 349) and a glimpse of the Roman Catholic Church of St. Paul the Apostle; the latter being at the S.W. corner of Columbus Avenue and W. 60th Street and is an outstanding feature of New York containing numerous works of art. No. 2 shows buildings near the Circle. These bear No's. 311 and 313-315. They are repeated in No. 3, being at the foot of the 23 story Gotham National Bank Building (No. 307). Note that the latter is not on the Circle as a thin veneer of structures line same.

September 4, 1938.
Views 1, 2 and 3.

P.L. Sperr

West 59th Street, south side, between Columbus Circle and Ninth Avenue, showing a clearance there extending to 58th Street. The direction of the view is eastward from a point near Ninth Avenue. At the far end of the parking space are several buildings; that with the white stripe is the Park Theatre. This is entered from the Circle where a corner abuts. The balance of the building is on 58th Street. In the background is the General Motors Bldg. and its neighbors, all on Broadway.

May 21, 1939
No's. 1-2

P. L. Sperr

West 59th Street, south side, between Columbus Circle and Ninth Avenue, showing a clearance there extending to 58th Street. The direction of the view is eastward from a point near Ninth Avenue. At the far end of the parking space are several buildings; that with the white stripe is the Park Theatre. This is entered from the Circle where a corner abuts. The balance of the building is on 58th Street. In the background is the General Motors Bldg. and its neighbors, all on Broadway.

May 21, 1939
No's. 1-2

P. L. Sperr

West 59th Street, north side, between Columbus Circle and Ninth Avenue, as photographed northward across the clearance between 58th and 59th Street's. The 23 story office structure at the right is the Gotham National Bank Bldg. This bears No. 303-7 West 59th Street and is slightly west of the Circle. In the left midground appears the twin buttresses of St. Paul the Apostle R. C. Church on Ninth Ave.

May 21, 1939
No's. 1-2-3

P. L. Sperr

West 59th Street, north side, between Columbus Circle and Ninth Avenue, as photographed northward across the clearance between 58th and 59th Street's. In the left midground appears the twin buttresses of St. Paul the Apostle R. C. Church on Ninth Ave.

April 19, 1941.

Columbus Avenue, north from W. 60th Street as photographed from the downtown 59th Street station of the 9th Avenue "El". At the left is a new apartment building at the N. W. corner of 60th Street. Above same is the 12 Regiment Armory. The Uppercue Building (70 Columbus Avenue) is opposite the Hotel Empire. Obscuring the latter is the towering Kent Garage.

June 6, 1940

P. L. Sperr

All view same except from different angles. 59th Street, east of ninth Avenue.
